All the editorial \rmatter has been set up afresh and much of it recast ; and \ra considerable amount of fresh material has been added. \r\rI desire to repeat with emphasis the acknowledgment \rmade in my earlier editions of my great indebtedness to \rprevious editors. It is a pious pleasure to make special \rmention of the immortal labours of Todd and Masson ; nor \rshould Newton and Keightley be forgotten. An editor is \rpowerless to estimate what he owes to them (above all, to \rMasson), and to others who have wrestled with the \rallusions of a poem that for its full elucidation would ex- \rhaust the last resources of scholarship. Some specific items, \rhowever, of my own obligations may be recorded here, \rwhile many instances are indicated in the course of the \r\rThe text is founded on that of Masson\'s "Globe" \redition, but with a simpler system of punctuation, such \ras I thought might be in rather closer conformity with the \r\roriginal. \r\rNearly all the biblical and classical references given in \rthis volume have been pointed out by, and taken from, \rother editors. \r\r\r\rvi PREFACE. \r\rA large proportion of the Milton references had their \rorigin in the Concordance to Milton\'s poems by the \rAmerican student Cleveland, a work of immense labour \rand great accuracy which has never, I think, received its \rdue. I may mention in passing that, to prevent miscon- \rception, I avoided consulting at all the Milton Lexicon \rpublished recently by another American student. On the \rother hand, I have used with much profit the scholarly and \rexhaustive dictionary of The Classical Mythology of Milton\'s \rEnglish Poems, by Mr C. G. Osgood, one of those fine \rstudies in English literature for which we have to thank the \rUniversity of Yale. \r\rThe extracts from the Milton MSS. are quoted (without, \rof course, any modernisation) from the beautiful facsimile \rpublished by the University Press, under the editorship of \rthe Vice-Master of Trinity College. The textual variations \rare shown so simply by the editor\'s very ingenious typo- \rgraphical arrangement that the work of collating is practically \rdone away. \r\rThe extracts from Milton\'s prose works are taken from \rthe edition published in "Bonn\'s Standard Library." Apart \rfrom my general indebtedness to this edition, I must note \rthat its footnotes are the source of many of my references to \rMilton\'s Christian Doctrine. \r\rAll the translations of passages from Dante, and most of \rthe Dante information, come from the editions of the \r"Temple" series. Except in a few specified cases, the \rpassages are such as had struck me. \r\rThe etymological material of the Glossary, together with \ra great deal of other miscellaneous information throughout \rthe volume, is summarised from standard works of reference. \rUnfortunately, in attempting to edit a vast work like \rParadise Lost, one has to "get up" all sorts of subjects \r\r\r\rPREFACE. v " \r\routside the scope of one\'s own circumscribed interests, and \rthis rather involves the affectation of knowledge. \r\rI owe not a little to the suggestions and criticisms of \rmany unknown correspondents; and in going through \rexamination-answers I have sometimes come across things \rthat I was very glad to make a note of which is not \rsurprising, now that English is taught so well in many \rschools. I recollect that the note on n. 497~ 5 02 came in \ra schoolboy\'s answer. \r\rThe Indexes, apart from some expansion of the second, \rwere compiled for me at the University Press; and it is a \rvery great satisfaction to express my gratitude to the reader, \ror readers, of the Press whose vigilance over the proof- \rsheets has -saved me from many slips. \r\rI hope now that I have made adequate acknowledgment \rof my obligations; and perhaps it will not be undue egotism \rto add that in the course of twenty years of editing one \rnecessarily accumulates a good deal of material and mis- \rcellanea. \r\r\r\rA. L. \r\r\r\rINTRODUCTION \r\r\r\rLIFE OF MILTON. \r\rMILTON\'S life falls into three clearly defined divisions. The \rfirst period ends with the poet\'s return from Italy in 1639; the \rsecond at the Restoration in 1660, when release from the fetters \rof politics enabled him to remind the world that he was a great \rpoet ; the third is brought to a close with his death in 1674. \rParadise Lost belongs to the last of these periods ; but we \rpropose to summarise briefly the main events of all three. \r\rJohn Milton was born on December 9, 1608, in London. He \rcame, in his own words, ex genere honesto. A family of Miltons \rhad been settled in Oxfordshire since the reign of Elizabeth. \rThe poet\'s father had been educated at an Oxford school, possibly \ras a chorister in one of the College choir-schools, and imbibing \rAnglican sympathies had conformed to the Established Church. \rFor this he was disinherited by his Roman Catholic father. He \rsettled in London, following the profession of scrivener. A \rscrivener combined the occupations of lawyer and law-stationer. \rIt appears to have been a lucrative calling ; certainly John Milton \r(the poet was named after the father) attained to easy circum- \rstances. He married about 1600, and had six children, of \rwhom several died young. The third child was the poet. \r\rThe elder Milton was evidently a man of considerable \rculture, in particular an accomplished musician, and a com- \rposer whose madrigals were deemed worthy of being printed \rside by side with those of Byrd, Orlando Gibbons and other \rleading musicians of the time. To him, no doubt, the poet \rowed the love of music of which we see frequent indications in \r\r\r\rXli INTRODUCTION. \r\rthe poems 1 . Realising, too, that in his son lay the promise \rand possibility of future greatness, John Milton took the utmost \rpains to have the boy adequately educated ; and the lines Ad \rPatrem show that the ties of affection between father and child \rwere of more than ordinary closeness. \r\rMilton was sent to St Paul\'s School about the year 1620. \rHere two influences, apart from those of ordinary school-life, may \rhave affected him particularly. The headmaster was a good \rEnglish scholar ; he published a grammar containing many \rextracts from English poets, notably Spenser ; it is reasonable \rto assume that he had not a little to do with the encouragement \rand guidance of Milton\'s early taste for English poetry 2 . Also, \rthe founder of St Paul\'s School, Colet, had prescribed as part \rof the school-course the study of certain early Christian writers, \rwhose influence is said to be directly traceable in Milton\'s poems \rand may in some cases have suggested his choice of sacred \rthemes 2 . While at St Paul\'s, Milton also had a tutor at home, \rThomas Young, a Scotchman, afterwards an eminent Puritan \rdivine the inspirer, doubtless, of much of his pupil\'s Puritan \rsympathies. And Milton enjoyed the signal advantage of \rgrowing up in the stimulating atmosphere of cultured home-life. \rMost men do not realise that the word \'culture\' signifies \ranything very definite or desirable before they pass to the \rUniversity; for Milton, however, home-life meant, from the \rfirst, not only broad interests and refinement, but active \rencouragement towards literature and study. In 1625 he left \rSt Paul\'s. Of his extant English poems 3 only one, On the \r\r1 Milton was very fond of the organ; see // Penseroso, 161, note. \rDuring his residence at Horton Milton made occasional journeys to \rLondon to hear, and obtain instruction (probably from Henry Lawes) \rin, music. It was an age of great musical development. See "Milton\'s \rKnowledge of Music" by Mr W. H. Hadow, in Milton Memorial \rLedtirts (1908). \r\r2 See the paper "Milton as Schoolboy and Schoolmaster" by \rMr A. F. Leach, read before the British Academy, Dec. 10, 1908. \r\r3 His paraphrases of Psalms cxiv. cxxxvi. scarcely come under this \rheading. Aubrey says in his quaint Life of Milton: "Anno Domini \r1619 he was ten yeares old, as by his picture [the portrait by Cornelius \rJansen] : and was then a poet." \r\r\r\rLIFE OF MILTON. Xlll \r\rDeath of a Fair Infant, dates from his school-days ; but we are \rtold that he had written much verse, English and Latin. And \rhis early training had done that which was all-important : it had \rlaid the foundation of the far-ranging knowledge which makes \rParadise Lost unique for diversity of suggestion and interest. \r\rMilton went to Christ\'s College, Cambridge, in the Easter \rterm of 1625, took his B.A. degree in 1629, proceeded M.A. in \r1632, and in the latter year left Cambridge. The popular view \rof Milton\'s connection with the University will be coloured for \rall time by Johnson\'s unfortunate story that for some unknown \' \roffence he " suffered the public indignity of corporal correction." \rFor various reasons this story is now discredited by the best \rjudges. It is certain, however, that early in 1626 Milton did have \rsome serious difficulty with his tutor, which led to his removal \rfrom Cambridge for a few weeks and his transference to another \rtutor on his return later in the term. He spoke of the incident \rbitterly at the time in one of his Latin poems, and he spoke of \rCambridge bitterly in after years. On the other hand he \rvoluntarily passed seven years at the University, and resented \rstrongly the imputations brought against him in the " Smectym- \rnuus" controversy that he had been in ill-favour with the \rauthorities s ^^4iis_j:ollege. Writing in 1642, he takes the \ropportunity "to acknowledge publicly with all grateful mind, \rthat more than ordinary favour and respect, which I found above \rany of my equals at the hands of those courteous and learned \rmen, the fellows of that college wherein I spent some years : who \rat my parting, after I had taken two degrees, as the manner is, \rsignified many ways how much better it would content them \rthat I would stay ; as by many letters full of kindness and loving \rrespect, both before that time, and long after, I was assured of \rtheir singular good affection towards me 1 ." And if we look into \rthose uncomplimentary allusions to Cambridge which date from \rthe controversial period of his life we see that the feeling they \r\r1 An Apology for Smectymmms, P. W. III. in. Perhaps Cambridge \rwould have been more congenial to Milton had he been sent to Emmanuel \rCollege, long a centre of Puritanism. Dr John Preston, then Master \rof the college, was a noted leader of the Puritan party. \r\r\r\rxiv INTRODUCTION. \r\rrepresent is hardly more than a phase of his theological bias. \rHe detested ecclesiasticism, and for him the two Universities \r(there is a fine impartiality in his diatribes) are the strongholds \rof what he detested : " nurseries of superstition " " not yet well \rrecovered from the scholastic grossness of barbarous ages" \rgiven up to "monkish and miserable sophistry," and unpro- \rgressive in their educational methods. But it may fairly be \rassumed that Milton the scholar and poet, who chose to spend \rseven years at Cambridge, owed to her more than Milton the \rfierce controversialist admitted or knew. A poet he had proved \rhimself before leaving the University in 1632. The short but \rexquisite ode At a Solemn Music^ and the Nativity Hymn \r(1629), were already written. \r\rMilton\'s father had settled at Horton in Buckinghamshire. \rThither the son retired in July, 1632. He had gone to Cambridge \rwith the intention of qualifying for some profession, perhaps the \rChurch 1 : This purpose was soon given up, and when Milton \rreturned to his father\'s house he seems to have made up his \rmind that there was no profession which he cared to enter. He \rwould choose the better part of studying and preparing himseli, \rby rigorous self-discipline and application, for the far-off divine \revent to which his whole life moved. \r\rIt was Milton\'s constant resolve to achieve something that \rshould vindicate the ways of God to men, something great that \rshould justify his own possession of unique powers powers of \rwhich, with no trace of egotism, he proclaims himself proudly \rconscious. The feeling finds repeated expression in his prose ; \rit is the guiding-star that shines clear and steadfast even through \rthe mists of politics. He has a mission to fulfil, a purpose \rto accomplish, no less than the most fanatic of religious en- \rthusiasts ; and the means whereby this end is to be attained are \r\r1 Cf. Milton\'s own words : " the church, to whose service, by the \rintentions of my parents and friends, I was destined of a child, and \rin my own resolutions" (The Reason of Church Government, P. W. \rII. 482). What kept him from taking orders was primarily his \robjection to Church discipline and government : he spoke of himself \ras " Church-outed by the prelates." \r\r\r\rLIFE OF MILTON. XV \r\rdevotion to religion, devotion to learning, and ascetic purity \r\rof life. \r\rThis period of self-centred isolation lasted from 1632 to 1638. \rGibbon tells us among the many wise things contained in that \rmost wise book the Autobiography, that every man has two \reducations : that which he receives from his teachers and that \rwhich he owes to himself ; the latter being infinitely the more \rimportant. During these five years Milton completed his \rsecond education ; ranging the whole world of classical 1 anti- \rquity and absorbing the classical genius so thoroughly that \rthe ancients were to him what they afterwards became to \rLandor, what they have never become to any other English \rpoet in the same degree, even as the very breath of his being ; \rpursuing, too, other interests, such as music, astronomy 2 and \rthe study of Italian literature; and combining these vast \rand diverse influences into a splendid equipment of hard-won, \rwell-ordered culture. The world has known many greater \rscholars in the technical, limited sense than Milton, but few \rmen, if any, who have mastered more things worth mastering \rin art, letters and scholarship 3 . It says much for the poet that \r\r1 He was closely familiar too with post-classical writers like Philo \rand the neo-Platonists ; nor must we forget the mediaeval element in \rhis learning, due often to Rabbinical teaching. \r\r2 Science " natural philosophy," as he terms it is one of the \rbranches of study advocated in his treatise On Education. Of his \rearly interest in astronomy there is a reminiscence in Paradise Lost, \rII. 70811; where "Milton is not referring to an imaginary comet, \rbut to one which actually did appear when he was a boy of 10 (1618), \rin the constellation called Ophiuchus. It was of enormous size, the \rtail being recorded as longer even than that of 1858. It was held \rresponsible by educated and learned men of the day for disasters. \rEvelyn says in his diary, \'The effects of that comet, 1618, still working \rin the prodigious revolutions now beginning in Europe, especially in \rGermany\'" (Professor Ray Lankester). \r\r3 Milton\'s poems with their undercurrent of perpetual allusion are \rthe best proof of the width of his reading ; but interesting supplementary \revidence is afforded by the Common-place Book discovered in 1874, and \rprinted by the Camden Society, 1876. It contains extracts from about \r80 different authors whose works Milton had studied. The entries seem \rto have been made in the period 163746. \r\r\r\rXVI INTRODUCTION. \r\rhe was sustained through this period of study, pursued ohne \rHast, ohne Rast, by the full consciousness that all would be \rcrowned by a masterpiece which should add one more testi- \rmony to the belief in that God who ordains the fates of men. \rIt says also a very great deal for the father who suffered his \rson to follow in this manner the path of learning. \r\rTrue, Milton gave more than one earnest of his future fame. \rThe dates of the early pieces D Allegro, II Penseroso, Arcades, \rCounts and Lycidas are not all certain ; but probably each was \rcomposed at Horton before 1638. Four of them have great \rautobiographic value as an indirect commentary, written from \rMilton\'s coign of seclusion, upon the moral crisis through which \rEnglish life and thought were passing, the clash between the \rcareless hedonism of the Cavalier world and the deepening \rausterity of Puritanism. In LlAllegro the poet holds the \rbalance almost equal between the two opposing tendencies. In \r// Penseroso it becomes clear to which side his sympathies are \rleaning. Comus is a covert prophecy of the downfall of the \rCourt-party, while Lycidas openly "foretells the mine" of the \rEstablished Church. The latter poem is the final utterance of \rMilton\'s lyric genius. Here he reaches, in Mr Mark Pattison\'s \rwords, the high-water mark of English verse ; and then the \rpity of it he resigns that place among the lyrici vates of which \rthe Roman singer was ambitious, and for nearly twenty years \rsuffers his lyre to hang mute and rusty in the temple of the \rMuses. \r\rThe composition of Lycidas may be assigned to the year \r1637. In the spring of the next year Milton started for Italy. \rIt was natural that he should seek inspiration in the land where \rmany English poets, from Chaucer to Shelley, have found it. \rMilton remained abroad some fifteen months. Originally he \rhad intended to include Sicily and Greece in his travels, but \rnews of the troubles in England hastened his return. He was \rbrought face to face with the question whether or not he should \rbear his part in the coming struggle ; whether without self- \rreproach he could lead any longer this life of learning and \rindifference to the public weal. He decided as we might have \rexpected that he would decide, though some good critics see \r\r\r\rLIFE OF MILTON. XV11 \r\rcause to regret the decision. Milton puts his position very \rclearly in his Defensio Secunda : " I thought it base to be \rtravelling for amusement abroad, while my fellow-citizens were \rfighting for liberty at home." And later : " I determined to \rrelinquish the other pursuits in which I was engaged, and to \rtransfer the whole force of my talents and my industry to this \rone important object" (i.e. the vindication of liberty). \r\rThe summer of 1639 (July) found Milton back in England. \rImmediately after his return he wrote the Epitaphium Damonis, \rthe beautiful elegy in which he lamented the death of his school \rfriend, Diodati. Lytidas was the last of the English lyrics : the \rEpitaphium, which should be studied in close connection with \rLycidas, the last of the long Latin poems. Thenceforth, for a \rlong spell, the rest was silence, so far as concerned poetry. The \rperiod which for all men represents the strength and maturity \rof manhood, which in the cases of other poets produces the best \rand most characteristic work, is with Milton a blank. In twenty \ryears he composed no more than a bare handful of Sonnets, \rand even some of these are infected by the taint of political \ranimus. Other interests claimed him the question of Church- \rreform, education, marriage, and, above all, politics. \r\rMilton\'s first treatise upon the government of the Church \r(Of Reformation in England} appeared in 1641. Others \rfollowed in quick succession. The abolition of Episcopacy \rwas the watchword of the enemies of the Anglican Church \rthe delenda est Carthago cry of Puritanism, and no one \renforced the point with greater eloquence than Milton. During \r1641 and 1642 he wrote five pamphlets on the subject. Mean- \rwhile he was studying the principles of education. On his \rreturn from Italy he had undertaken the training of his \rnephews. This led to consideration of the best educational \rmethods ; and in the Tractate of Education, 1644, Milton \rassumed the part of educational theorist. Milton\'s salary was 288, in \rmodern money about 900. \r\r\r\rLIFE OF MILTON. \r\r\r\rXIX \r\r\r\rThere was nothing distasteful about his duties. He drew up \rthe despatches to foreign governments, translated state-papers, \rand served as interpreter to foreign envoys. Had his duties \rstopped here his acceptance of the post would, I think, have \rproved an unqualified gain. It brought him into contact with the \rfirst men in the state, gave him a practical insight into the \rworking of national affairs and the motives of human action ; in \ra word, furnished him with that experience of life which is \ressential to all poets who aspire to be something more than \r"the idle singers of an empty day." But unfortunately the \rsecretaryship entailed the necessity of defending at every turn \rthe past course of the revolution and the present policy of the \rCouncil. Milton, in fact, held a perpetual brief as advocate for \rhis party. Hence the endless and unedifying controversies into \rwhich he drifted ; controversies which wasted the most precious \ryears of his life, warped, as some critics think, his nature, and \reventually cost him his eyesight. \r\rBetween 1649 anc ^ 1660 Milton produced no less than eleven \rpamphlets. Several of these arose out of the publication of the \rfamous Eikon Basilike, The book was printed in 1649 and \rcreated so extraordinary a sensation that Milton was asked to \rreply to it ; and did so with Eikonoklastes. Controversy of this \rbarren type has the inherent disadvantage that once started it may \rnever end. The Royalists commissioned the Leyden professor, \rSalmasius, to prepare a counterblast, the Defensio Regia, and \rthis in turn was met by Milton\'s Pro Popiilo Anglicano Defensio^ \r1651, over the preparation of which he lost what little power of \reyesight remained 1 . Salmasius retorted, and died before his \r\r1 Perhaps this was the saddest part of the episode. Milton tells us \rin the Defensio Secunda that his eyesight was injured by excessive study \rin boyhood : " from twelve years of age I hardly ever left my studies or \rwent to bed before midnight." Continual reading and writing increased \rthe infirmity, and by 1650 the sight of the left eye had gone. He was \rwarned that he must not use the other for book-work. Unfortunately \rthis was just the time when the Commonwealth stood most in need of \rhis services. If Milton had not written the first Defence he might have \rretained his partial vision, at least for a time. The choice lay between \r\r\r\rXX INTRODUCTION. \r\rsecond farrago of scurrilities was issued : Milton was bound to \ranswer, and the Defensio Secunda appeared in 1654. Neither \rof the combatants gained anything by the dispute ; while the \rsubsequent development of the controversy in which Milton \rcrushed the Amsterdam pastor and professor, Morus, goes far to \rprove the contention of Mr Mark Pattison, that it was an evil \rday when the poet left his study at Horton to do battle for the \rCommonwealth amid the vulgar brawls of the market-place . \r\r"Not here, O Apollo, \rWere haunts meet for thee." \r\rFortunately this poetic interregnum in Milton\'s life was not \rdestined to last much longer. The Restoration came, a blessing \rin disguise, and in 1660 J the ruin of Milton\'s political party \rand of his personal hopes, the absolute overthrow of the cause \rfor which he had fought for twenty years, left him free. The \rauthor of Lycidas could once more become a poet. \r\rMuch has been written upon this second period, 1639 60. \rWe saw what parting of the ways confronted Milton on his \rreturn from Italy. Did he choose aright ? Should he have \rcontinued upon the path of learned leisure ? There are writers \rwho argue that Milton made a mistake. A poet, they say, \rshould keep clear of political strife : fierce controversy can \rbenefit no man : who touches pitch must expect to be, certainly \rwill be, defiled : Milton sacrificed twenty of the best years of \rhis life, doing work which an underling could have done and \rwhich was not worth doing : another Comus might have been \rwritten, a loftier Lycidas : that literature should be the poorer \rby the absence of these possible masterpieces, that the second \r\rprivate good and public duty. He repeated in 1650 the sacrifice of 1639. \rAll this is brought out in his Second Defence. By the spring of 1652 \rMilton was quite blind He was then in his forty-fourth year. Probably \rthe disease from which he suffered was amaurosis. See the Appendix \r(pp. 682, 683) on P. L. HI. 22 26. Throughout P. L. and Samson \rAgonistes there are frequent references to his affliction. \r\r1 Milton probably began Paradise Lost in 1658; but it was not till \rthe Restoration in 1660 that he definitely resigned all his political \rhopes, and became quite free to realise his poetical ambition. \r\r\r\rLIFE OF MILTON. xxi \r\rgreatest genius which England has produced should in a way \rbe the " inheritor of unfulfilled renown," is and must be a thing \rentirely and terribly deplorable. This is the view of the purely \rliterary critic. \r\rThere remains the other side of the question. It may fairly \rbe contended that had Milton elected in 1639 to live the scholar\'s \rlife apart from " the action of men," Paradise Lost, as we have \rit, or Samson Agonistes could never have been written. Know- \rledge of life and human nature, insight into the problems oi \rmen\'s motives and emotions, grasp of the broader issues of the \rhuman tragedy, all these were essential to the author of an epic \rpoem ; they could only be obtained through commerce with the \rworld ; they would have remained beyond the reach of a recluse. \rDryden complained that Milton saw nature through the spec- \rtacles of books : we might have had to complain that he saw \rmen through the same medium. Fortunately it is not so : and \rit is not so because at the age of thirty-two he threw in his \rfortunes with those of his country ; like the diver in Schiller\'s \rballad he took the plunge which was to cost him so dear. The \rmere man of letters will never move the world. ^Cschylus fought \rat Marathon : Shakespeare was practical to the tips of his \rfingers ; a better business man than Goethe there was not \rwithin a radius of a hundred miles of Weimar. \r\rThis aspect of the question is emphasised by Milton himself. \rThe man, he says, " who would not be frustrate of his hope to \rwrite well hereafter in laudable things, ought himself to be a \rtrue poem , that is, a composition and pattern of the best and \rhonourablest things; not presuming to sing high praises of heroic \rmen, or famous cities, unless he have in himself the experience \rand the practice of all that which is praiseworthy 1 ." Again, in \restimating the qualifications which the writer of an epic such as \rhe contemplated should possess, he is careful to include \r"insight into all seemly and generous arts and affairs 2 ." \r\rTruth usually lies half-way between extremes : perhaps it \rdoes so here. No doubt, Milton did gain very greatly by \r\r1 An Apology for Smectymnuus, P. W. in. 118. \ra The Reason of Church Government, P. W. II. 481. \r\r\r\rxxii INTRODUCTION. \r\rbreathing awhile the larger air of public life, even though \rthat air was often tainted by much impurity. No doubt, too, \rtwenty years of contention must have left their mark even on \rMilton. In one of the very few places where he " abides our \rquestion," Shakespeare writes (Sonnet CXI.) : \r\r"OI for my sake do you with Fortune chide, \rThe guilty goddess of my harmful deeds, \rThat did not better for my life provide, \rThan public means, which public manners breeds : \rThence comes it that my name receives a brand ; \rAnd almost thence my nature is subdued \rTo what it works in, like the dyer\'s hand." \r\rMilton\'s genius was subdued in this way. If we compare \rhim, the Milton of the great epics and of Samson Agonistes, \rwith Homer or Shakespeare and none but the greatest can \rbe his parallel we find in him a certain want of humanity, \ra touch of narrowness. He lacks the large-heartedness, the \rgenial, generous breadth of Shakespeare ; the sympathy and \rsense of the lacrimce rerum that even in Troilus and Cressida or \rTimon of Athens are there for those who have eyes wherewith \rto see them. Milton reflects in some degree the less gracious \raspects of Puritanism, its intolerance, want of humour, one-sided \rintensity ; and it seems natural to assume that this narrowness \rwas to a great extent the price he paid for twenty years of cease- \rless special pleading and dispute. The real misfortune of his \rlife lay in the fact that he fell on evil, angry days when there \rwas no place for moderate men. He had to be one of two \rthings : either a controversialist or a student : there was no via \rmedia. Probably he chose aright ; but we could wish that the \rconditions under which he chose had been different. And he \ris so great, so majestic in the nobleness of his life, in the purity \rof his motives, in the self-sacrifice of his indomitable devotion \rto his ideals, that we could wish not even to seem to pronounce \rjudgment at all. \r\rThe last part of Milton\'s life, 1660 74, passed quietly. At \rthe age of fifty-two he was thrown back upon poetry, and could \rat length discharge his self-imposed obligation. XXV \r\r\r\rPARADISE LOST. \r\rWe have seen that the dominating idea of Milton\'s life was \rhis resolve to write a great poem great in theme, in style, in \rattainment. The second period extends from 1640 to 1642. And it is not, I think, fanciful to consider \rthat Paradise Lost entered on a fresh stage about 1640, because \rbetween that year and 1642 Milton\'s plans underwent a twofold \rchange by which the character of the poem was entirely altered. \r\rFirst, the subject for which he had shown so decided a bias \ris discarded : after 1639 no mention is made of King Arthur. \rWe have no hint of the cause which led Milton to drop the \rsubject ; but it may well have lain in his increasing re- \rpublicanism. He could not have treated the theme from an \r\r1 P. W. ii. 47 8, 479. \r\r\r\rPARADISE LOST. xxxiii \r\runfavourable standpoint. Only a Royalist could have retold \rthe story, making it illustrate " the divine right of kings," and \rembodying in the character of the blameless monarch the \rCavalier conception of Charles I. Milton with his intense \rearnestness was not the poet to build a long work on what he \rhad found to be mainly fiction. But if the history of the book be obscure, its \rvalue is not ; for it contains now in Milton\'s autograph, now \rin other, unidentified handwritings the original drafts of several \rof his early poems : notably of Arcades, Lycidas and Camus, \rtogether with many of the Sonnets. The volume is not a \rrandom collection of scattered papers bound together after \rMilton\'s death : it exists (apart from its sumptuous modern \rinvestiture) exactly in the same form as that wherein Milton \rknew and used it two centuries and a half agone. And this \rpoint is important because the order of the pages, and, by \rconsequence, of their contents, is an index to the order of the \rcomposition of the poems. Milton, about the year 1631, had \rhad the sheets of paper stitched together and then worked \rthrough the little volume, page on page, inserting his pieces as \rthey were written. They cover a long period, from 16 to 1658: \rthe earlier date being marked by the second Sonnet, the later \rby the last of the series " Methought I saw." It is rather more- \rthan half way through the MS. that we light on the entries \rwhich have so direct a bearing on the history of Paradise Lost. \rThese are notes, written by Milton himself (probably in \r1641), and occupying seven pages of the manuscript, on subjects \rwhich seemed to him suitable, in varying degrees of appropriate- \rness, for his poem. Some of the entries are very brief concise \rjottings down, in two or three words, of any theme that struck \rhim. Others are more detailed : the salient features of some \repisode in history are selected, and a sketch of the best method \rof treating them added. In a few instances these sketches are \rfilled in with much minuteness and care: the \'economy\' or \rarrangement of the poem is marked out the action traced from \rpoint to point. But, Paradise Lost apart, this has been done in \ronly a few cases a half dozen, at most. Milton made Moses the speaker of the prologue in \rthe third draft because so much of the subject-matter of \rParadise Lost is drawn from the Mosaic books of the Old \rTestament. But the appearance of a descendant of Adam, \reven in a prologue, where much latitude is allowed by con- \rvention, seems an awkward prelude to scenes coincident with \rAdam\'s own creation. It is far more natural that, before the \rsubject of man\'s fall is touched upon at all, we should be told \rwho man is, and that this first mention of him should come \rfrom the supernatural beings who had, or might have, witnessed \rthe actual creation of the universe and its inhabitants. The \rexplanation, too, why Moses is able to assume his natural body \ris very forced. And altogether this fourth draft exhibits more \rof drama, less of spectacle, than its predecessor. \r\rWith regard to the subject, therefore, thus much is clear : \ras early as 1641 2 Milton has manifested an unmistakeable \rpreference for the story of the lost Paradise, and the evidence \rof the Trinity MSS. coincides with the testimony of Aubrey and \rPhillips, who say that the poet did, about 1642, commence the \rcomposition of a drama on this theme of which drama the \ropening verses of Paradise Lost, book IV. Milton may have written \rtwo or three hundred lines, have kept them in his desk, and \rthen, years afterward, when the project was resumed, have made \ruse of them where opportunity offered. Had the poem, however, \rbeen completed in accordance with his original conception we \rshould have had a tragedy, not an epic. \r\rOf this there is abundant proof. The third and fourth \rsketches, as has been observed, are dramatic. On the first \rpage of these entries, besides those lists of dramatis persona \rwhich we have treated as the first and second sketches, stand \rthe words "other Tragedies," followed by the enumeration of \rseveral feasible subjects. (i.e. tragedies). \r\r\r\rPARADISE LOST. xli \r\rWherever Milton has outlined the treatment of any of the \rScriptural themes a tragedy is clearly indicated. With the romantic stage of the Elizabethans Milton \rappears to have felt little sympathy 2 : else he would scarce have \rwritten // Penseroso, 101, 102. L. d \r\r\r\rxlii INTRODUCTION, \r\rLost we find in them the familiar features of Athenian drama \rcertain signs eloquent of the source on which the poet has \rdrawn. \r\rLet us, for example, glance at the draft of Adam unparadiz* d. \rMilton has kept the \'unities\' of place and time. The scene \rdoes not change ; it is set in some part of Eden, and everything \rrepresented before the eyes of the audience occurs at the same \rspot. But whoso regards the unity of place must suffer a \rportion of the action to happen off the stage not enacted in \rthe presence of the audience (as in a modern play where the \rscene changes), but reported. In Samson Agonistes Milton \remploys the traditional device of the Greek tragedians he \rrelates the catastrophe by the mouth of a messenger. So here : \rthe temptation by the serpent is not represented on the scene : \rit is described partly by Lucifer, "relating, and insulting in \rwhat he had don to the destruction of man"; partly by an angel \rwho informs the Chorus of the manner of the fall. Again, the \runity of time is observed. The time over which the action of a \rtragedy might extend, according to the usual practice of the \rGreek dramatists, was twenty-four hours. In Samson Agonistes \rthe action begins at sunrise and ends at noon, thus occupying \rseven or eight hours. In Adam unparaditfd the action would \rcertainly not exceed the customary twenty-four hours. Again a \rChorus is introduced (sure sign of classical influence), and not \ronly introduced, but handled exactly as Milton, following his \rGreek models, has handled it in Samson Agonistes : that is to \rsay, closely identified with the action of the tragedy, even as \rAristotle recommends that it should be. Further, in the fourth \rscheme the division into acts is carefully avoided an advance \rthis on the third scheme. The \rwheel had come full circle with a vengeance. \r\rThis first edition of Paradise Lost raises curious points 1 of \rbibliography into which there is no need to enter here ; but we \rmust note three things. In the earlier copies issued to the \rpublic there were no prose Arguments ; these (written, we may \rsuppose, by Milton himself) were printed all together and \rinserted at the commencement of each of the later volumes of \r\r\r\r1 For example, no less than nine distinct title-pages of this edition \rhave been traced. This means that, though the whole edition was \rprinted in 1667, only a limited number of copies were bound up and \rissued in that year. The rest would be kept in stock, unbound, and \rpublished in instalments, as required. Hence new matter could be \rinserted (such as the prose Arguments)^ and in each instalment it would \rbe just as easy to bind up a new title-page as to use the old one. Often \rthe date had to be changed : and we find that two of these pages bear \rthe year 1667; four, 1668 ; and three, 1669. Seven have Milton\'s \rname in full ; two, only his initials. It seems that the number of copies printed in the first \redition was 1500; and the statement of another payment made \rby the publisher to Milton on account of the sale of the book \rshows that by April 26, 1669, i.e. a year and a half after the date \rof publication, 1300 copies had been disposed of. \r\rIn 1674 the second edition was issued with several changes. \rFirst, the epic (said to be 670 lines longer than the ^Eneid} \rwas divided into twelve books, a more Vergilian number, by the \rsubdivision of books VII. and X. It was to the second \redition that the commendatory verses by Samuel Barrow and \rAndrew Marvell were prefixed. Four years later, 1678, came \rthe third edition, and in 1688 the fourth. This last was the \rwell-known folio published by Tonson ; Paradise Regained and \rSamson Agonistes were bound up with some copies of it, so that \rMilton\'s three great works were obtainable in a single volume. \rThe first annotated edition of Paradise Lost was that edited by \rPatrick Hume in 1695, being the sixth reprint. To the general \rpublic epic poetry will never appeal, more especially if it be \rsteeped in the classical feeling that pervades Paradise Lost ; \rbut there must have been a goodly number of scholars and \rlettered readers to welcome the work else why these successive \reditions, appearing at no very lengthy intervals? One thing, \rdoubtless, which prejudiced its popularity was the personal \rresentment of the Royalist classes at Milton\'s political actions. \rThey could not forget his long identification with republicanism ; \rand there was much in the poem itself covert sneers and \rgibes which would repel many who were loyal to the Church \rand the Court. Further, the style of Paradise Lost was \rsomething very different from the prevailing tone of the \rliterature then current and popular. Milton was the last of the \rElizabethans, a lonely survival lingering on into days when \rFrench influence was beginning to dominate English taste. \rEven the metre of his poem must have sounded strange to ears \rfamiliarised to the crisp clearness and epigrammatic ring of the \rrhymed couplet 1 . Yet, in spite of these obstacles, many whose \rpraise was worth the having were proud of Milton : they felt \rthat he had done honour to his country. He was accorded that \rwhich he had sought so earnestly acceptance as a great \rnational poet ; and it is pleasant to read how men of letters \rand social distinction would pay visits of respect to him, and \rhow the white-winged Fame bore his name and reputation \rabroad, so that foreigners came to England for the especial \rpurpose of seeing him. And their visits were the prelude of \rthat foreign renown and influence from which he seemed to \rhave cut himself off when he made his native tongue the \rmedium of his great work. " Milton was the first English \rpoet to inspire respect and win fame for our literature on the \rContinent, and to his poetry was due, to an extent that has not \ryet been fully recognised, the change which came over European \rideas in the eighteenth century with regard to the nature and \rscope of the epic. Paradise Lost was the mainstay of those \r\r1 Cf. Marvell\'s "Commendatory Verses," 45 54. \r\r\r\rxlviii INTRODUCTION. \r\rcritics who dared to vindicate, in the face of French classicism, \rthe rights of the imagination over the reason in poetry 1 ." \r\rThere has been much discussion about the \'sources\' of \rParadise Lost, and writers well nigh as countless as Vallom- \rbrosa\'s autumn leaves have been thrust forth from their \robscurity to claim the honour of having \'inspired\' (as the \rphrase is) the great epic. Most of these unconscious claimants \rwere, like enough, unknown to Milton ; but some of them do \rseem to stand in a relation which demands recognition. \r\rI should place first the Latin tragedy Adamus Exul (1601), \rwritten in his youth by the great jurist Hugo Grotius after the \rmodel of Seneca. What authority he had for this legend Voltaire does not \rsay. It is not alluded to by any of Milton\'s contemporary bio- \rgraphers. It may have been a mere invention by some ill-wisher \rof the poet, a piece of malicious gossip circulated out of political \rspite against the great champion of republicanism. It is impossible that \rMilton read a line of the works himself ; if he knew them at all, \rit must have been through the assistance of some reader or \rtranslator; and considering how many details concerning the \rlast years of Milton\'s life have survived, it is exceeding curious \rthat this reader or translator should have escaped mention, and \rthat the Vondelian theory should not have been heard of till a \rcentury after the poet\'s death. For there were plenty of people \rready to do him an ill-turn and damage his repute ; and \rplagiarism from his Dutch contemporary would have been \ran excellent cry to raise. There is no reason for \rthinking that he was not the author of sacred poems, as Bede \rrepresents him to have been ; but there is also no possibility of \rbelieving that the Paraphrase, as we have it, was written by \rhim. So \rmuch is simply a matter of history ; and to claim for Milton or \rany other writer who chose this theme the merit of absolute \roriginality is simply to ignore history. L. \r\r\r\rIviii INTRODUCTION. \r\r\r\r\\ \r\r\r\rTHE STORY OF THE POEM. \r\r\r\rA sketch of the action of the whole poem, following the \rsequence of the twelve books, may be useful to those who are \racquainted only with parts of Paradise Lost : \r\rI. The scene Hell the time nine days after the expulsion \rof Satan and his followers from Heaven. They lie on the \rburning lake, stupefied. Satan first recovers, rouses Beelzebub, \rdiscusses with him their position, and then makes his way from \rthe lake to a " dreary plain " of dry land. Beelzebub follows ; \rSatan calls to his comrades to do likewise. Rising on the wing \rthey reach the same firm land. Their numbers and names \rdescribed. They range themselves in battle-array before Satan, \rwho addresses them. They may still (he says) regain Heaven ; \ror there may be other worlds to win in particular, a new world, \rinhabited by new-created beings, of which report had spoken : \rlet these matters be duly conferred of. Straightway, a vast \rpalace Pandemonium is made, to serve as council-chamber. \rHere a council is held ; only the great Angels are present. \r\rII. The scene at first Pandemonium ; the debate begins. \rSatan invites their counsel "who can advise may speak." \rMoloch, Belial and Mammon speak their several counsels : \rlast Beelzebub, who reverts to Satan\'s hint of the new world. \rWhy not ruin it ? or make it their own ? or win its inhabitants \rto their side? What better revenge against the Almighty? \rThe plan approved but who will discover this world ? None \rvolunteer : and then Satan offers to undertake the journey. \rHis offer accepted; the council leaving Pandemonium breaks \rup ; the result announced to the rest of the Angels. How they \rpass the time till his return some exploring Hell (now more \rclosely described). Meanwhile he reaches Hell-gates, is suffered \rto pass by Sin and Death, voyages through Chaos (described), \rand at last comes within sight of the Universe hung in space \r(i.e. Chaos). We leave him directing his course towards the \rWorld. \r\r\r\rPARADISE LOST. lix \r\rIII. The scene at first Heaven. The Almighty perceives \rSatan, points him out to the Son, tells what his design is, and \rits destined success ; tells also that Man will be saved ultimately \rif he can find a Redeemer. " The Son of God freely offers \rhimself a ransom for Man " ; is accepted by the Father, and \rpraised by the Angelic host. Meanwhile the scene changing \rSatan, having reached the outer surface (described) of the \rUniverse, wanders through various regions (described), until, \rcoming to the single opening in the surface, he descends into \rthe inside of the Universe. He arrives at the sphere of the \rSun ; disguising himself as a young Angel from Heaven, en- \rquires from Uriel, the Sun-spirit, the way to Earth pretending \r" desire to behold the new Creation " ; is directed by Uriel, \rdescends again, and alights on Mt Niphates. \r\rIV. There, pausing awhile, he gives way to regret that he \rhas rebelled, and rage at his outcast state ; passion distorts his \rface, so that Uriel, watching, now knows him for an evil spirit. \rThence, recovering self-control, Satan journeys on towards \rEden, the main scene (described) ; sees Adam and Eve (famous \rdescription of them) ; overhears what they say concerning the \rTree of Knowledge, and perceives at once the means whereby \rto compass their fall At nightfall he essays to tempt Eve in a \rdream ; is discovered by Gabriel, who, warned by Uriel, has \rdescended to Eden to defend Man. A battle between Satan \rand Gabriel imminent, but averted. Satan flies. \r\rV The scene still Eden. A further picture of Adam and \rEve their worship and work. Raphael (the scene having \rchanged for a brief space to Heaven) comes to warn them of \rtheir danger, at the bidding of the Almighty so that Man, if he \rfalls, may fall knowingly, by his own fault. Raphael received \rand entertained ; admonishes Adam ; explains who his enemy \ris, and why . which leads to an account of the rebellion in \rHeaven its beginning described. \r\rVI. The scene of the events narrated by Raphael Heaven. \rHe describes the three days\' war in Heaven, at the end of which \rSatan and his followers were cast into Hell. The warning to \rAdam repeated. \r\r\r\rx INTRODUCTION. \r\rVII. The scene Eden. Raphael describes the Creation of \rthe World, which is accomplished by the Son of God. \r\rVIII. The scene the same. Adam enquires concerning \rthe stars and Heavenly bodies ; Raphael answers doubtfully. \rAdam recounts his own first experience of Eden how the \rAlmighty forbade him to touch the Tree of Knowledge, under \rpain of what penalty ; how he first saw Eve. The day declines, \rand Raphael departs once more warning Adam. \r\rIX. The scene the same. "Adam and Eve... go forth to \rtheir labours, which Eve proposes to divide in several places, \reach labouring apart." Adam dissuades ; she persisting, he \ryields. So Satan (in the form of a serpent) finds her alone and \rtempts her. She eats of the fruit and induces Adam to do so. \rTheir sense of sin and shame. \r\rX. Ixi \r\r\r\rMILTON\'S PREFACE ON "THE VERSE "OF \rPARADISE LOST. \r\rMilton\'s attitude towards rhyme reminds us of the condem- \rnations showered on it by Elizabethan critics. Ascham in the \rSchoolmaster (1570) sneers at "our rude beggerly ryming, brought \rfirst into Italic by Gothes and Hunnes, whan all good verses \rand all good learning to, were destroyed by them... and at last \rreceyued into England by men of excellent wit indeede, but of \rsmall learning, and lesse judgement in that behalfe." "Barba- \rrous " is his darling epithet for rhymed verse. Puttenham is of \ra like mind, waving aside " the rhyming poesie of the barbarians,\'"\' \rand Webbe in his Discourse of English Poetry (1586) takes up \rthe tale, ridiculing it as " tinkerly verse " " brutish poesie " \r" a great decay of the good order of versifying." Why Milton \rshould have adopted the same position as these Elizabethan \rcritics who approached the question in a spirit of the merest \rpedantry, and based their objections to rhyme solely on the \rfact that, as a metrical principle, it was not employed by the \rancients, it is not easy to say. He uses rhyme occasionally in \rSamson Agonistes, in spite of his denunciation of it here ; and \rhis own early poems are sufficient refutation of the heresy that \rtherein lies " no true musical delight." Moreover, though he \rappeals to the example of some European poets " 01 prime \rnote" in support of his view, yet he must have foreseen the \robvious and just retort that the weight of " custom " was against \rhim, and that, in particular, the Italian exponents 01 versi \rsciolti whom he could cite on his side made a poor showing \rbeside those great masters of rhyme Dante, Ariosto, Tasso 1 \rto whom he himself owed so much. His contemptuous dis- \rmissal of what " in every country of modern Europe had been \radopted as the basis of metrical composition 2 " was ^character- \ristic touch of his resentment of criticism and defiance of \rauthority. \r\r1 See, however, p. 367. \r\r2 Courthope. \r\r\r\rIxii INTRODUCTION. \r\rThere is a polemical tone in his remarks, as though he were \rreplying to some unnamed antagonist ; and I cannot help \rthinking that this preface was meant to be his contribution to \rthe controversy then raging over the comparative advantages of \rrhymed and unrhymed metres on the stage. In fact, significant \rin itself, Milton\'s opinion becomes doubly so if regarded from \rthe standpoint of his contemporaries. Hardly could they fail to \rsee in it a retort to what Dryden had written in the behalf of \rrhyme notably in his Essay of Dramatic Poesy (1665), in \rwhich the rhymed couplet had been set forth as the best vehicle \rof dramatic expression. In play after play Dryden had put his \rtheory into practice : others had followed his example : to \rrhyme or not to rhyme that had become the great question; \rand here was Milton brushing the matter on one side as of no \rmoment, with the autocratic dictum that rhyme was a vain and \rfond thing with which a " sage and serious " poet need have no \rcommerce. His readers must have detected the contemporary \rapplication of his words just as later on they must have \rinterpreted his preface to Samson Agonistes, with its pointed \reulogy of the Greek stage and its depreciation of Restoration \rtragedy (and "other common interludes"), as a counterblast to \rthe comparison which Dryden had drawn between the modern \rand the classical drama, in the interests of the former. In its earlier stages, exemplified by \rworks like Gorboduc, the metre suffered from the former \rtendency. It either closed with a strong pause at the end of \revery line, or just struggled to the climax of the couplet. \rFurther it never extended until Marlowe took the " drumming \rdecasyllabon " into his hands, broke up the fetters of the \rcouplet-form, and by the process of overflow carried on the \rrhythm from verse to verse according as the sense required. \rIt is in his plays that we first get verse in which variety of \rcadence and pause and beat takes the place of rhyme. Milton \rentered on the heritage that Marlowe and Shakespeare be- \rqueathed, and brought blank verse to its highest pitch of \rperfection as an instrument of narration. \r\rBriefly, that perfection lies herein : if we examine a page of \rParadise Lost we find that what the poet has to say is, for the \rmost part, conveyed, not in single lines, nor in rigid couplets \rbut in flexible combinations of verses, which wait upon his \rmeaning, not twisting or constraining the sense, but suffering it \rto be " variously drawn out," so that the thought is merged in \rits expression. \r\rThese combinations, or paragraphs, are informed by a \rperfect internal concent and rhythm 1 held together by a chain \rof harmony With a writer less sensitive to sound this free \rmethod of versifying would result in mere chaos. B., M.D. \r\r\r\rON PARADISE LOST. \r\rWHEN I beheld the Poet blind, yet bold, \r\rIn slender book his vast design unfold, \r\rMessiah crowned, God\'s reconciled decree, \r\rRebelling Angels, the Forbidden Tree, \r\rHeaven, Hell, Earth, Chaos, all ; the argument \r\rHeld me a while misdoubting his intent, \r\rThat he would ruin (for I saw him strong) \r\rThe sacred truths to fable and old song \r\r(So Samson groped the temple\'s posts in spite), \r\rThe world o\'ei whelming to revenge his sight. 10 \r\r\r\rCOMMENDATORY VERSES. 3 \r\rYet as I read, soon growing less severe, \rI liked his project, the success did fear; \rThrough that wide field how he his way should find \rO\'er which lame Faith leads Understanding blind ; \rLest he perplexed the things he would explain, \rAnd what was easy he should render vain. \r\rOr, if a work so infinite he spanned, \rJealous I was that some less skilful hand \r(Such as disquiet always what is well, \rAnd by ill imitating would excel) 20 \r\rMight hence presume the whole Creation\'s day \rTo change in scenes, and show it in a play. \r\rPardon me, mighty Poet; nor despise \rMy causeless, yet not impious, surmise. \rBut I am now convinced, and none will dare \rWithin thy labours to pretend a share. \rThou hast not missed one thought that could be fit, \rAnd all that was improper dost omit ; \rSo that no room is here for writers left, \rBut to detect their ignorance or theft. 30 \r\rThat majesty which through thy work doth reign \rDraws the devout, deterring the profane. \rAnd things divine thou treat\'st of in such state \rAs them preserves, and thee, inviolate. \rAt once delight and horror on us seize ; \rThou sing\'st with so much gravity and ease, \rAnd above human flight dost soar aloft \rWith plume so strong, so equal, and so soft. \rThe bird named from that Paradise you sing \rSo never flags, but always keeps on wing. 4^ \r\rWhere could\'st thou words of such a compass find? \rWhence furnish such a vast expense of mind? \rJust Heaven, thee like Tiresias to requite, \rRewards with prophecy thy loss of sight. \r\rWell might\'st thou scorn thy readers to allure \rWith tinkling rime, of thy own sense secure ; \r\rI 2 \r\r\r\rCOMMENDATORY VERSES. \r\rWhile the Town-Bayes writes all the while and spells, \r\rAnd, like a pack-horse, tires without his bells. \r\rTheir fancies like our bushy points appear; \r\rThe poets tag them, we for fashion wear. 50 \r\rI too, transported by the mode, offend, \r\rAnd while I meant to praise thee, must commend. \r\rThy verse created like thy theme sublime, \r\rIn number, weight, and measure, needs not rime. \r\rA. M. \r\r\r\rTHE VERSE 1 . \r\r\r\rThe measure is English heroic verse, without rime, as that \rof Homer in Greek, and of Virgil in Latin; rime being no \rnecessary adjunct or true ornament of poem or good verse, in \rlonger works especially, but the invention of a barbarous age, to \rset off wretched matter and lame metre ; graced indeed since by \rthe use of some famous modern poets, carried away by custom, \rbut much to their own vexation, hindrance, and constraint to \rexpress many things otherwise, and for the most part worse, \rthan else they would have expressed them. Not without cause, \rtherefore, some both Italian and Spanish poets of prime note \rhave rejected rime both in longer and shorter works, as have \ralso, long since, our best English tragedies ; as a thing of itself, \rto all judicious ears, trivial and of no true musical delight ; \rwhich consists only in apt numbers, fit quantity of syllables, \rand the sense variously drawn out from one verse into another, \rnot in the jingling sound of like endings, a fault avoided by the \r\r1 Preceded by some remarks from the publisher: \rThe Printer to the Reader. \r\rCourteous Reader^ there was no Argument at first intended to the \rbook; but for the satisfaction of many that have desired it, I have \rprocured it, and withal a reason of that which stumbled many others, \rwhy the poem rimes not. S. Simmons. \r\r\r\r6 TJII; VERSE. \r\rlearned ancients both in poetry and all good oratory. This \rneglect then of rime so little is to be taken for a defect, though \rit may seem so perhaps to vulgar readers, that it rather is to be \resteemed an example set, the first in English, of ancient liberty \rrecovered to heroic poem from the troublesome and modern \rbondage of riming. \r\r\r\rBOOK I. \r\r\r\rTHE ARGUMENT. \r\rThis First Book proposes, first in brief, the whole subject, Man\'s \rdisobedience, and the loss thereupon of Paradise, wherein he was \rplaced : then touches the prime cause of his fall, the Serpent, or rather \rSatan in the Serpent; who revolting from God, and drawing to his \rside many legions of Angels, was by the command of God driven out \rof Heaven with all his crew into the great Deep. Which action passed \rover, the Poem hastes into the midst of things; presenting Satan with \rhis Angels now fallen into Hell, described here, not in the Centre (for \rHeaven and Earth may be supposed as yet not made, certainly not yet \raccursed) but in a place of utter darkness, fitliest called Chaos: here \rSatan with his Angels lying on the burning lake, thunderstruck and \rastonished, alter a certain space recovers, as from confusion; calls up \rhim who, next in order and dignity, lay by him ; they confer of their \rmiserable fall. Satan awakens all his legions, who lay till then in the \rsame manner confounded; they rise: their numbers, array of battle, \rtheir chief leaders named, according to the idols known afterwards in \rCanaan and the countries adjoining. To these Satan directs his speech; \rcomforts them with hope yet of regaining Heaven; but tells them lastly \rof a new world and new kind of creature to be created, according to an \rancient prophecy or report in Heaven ; for that Angels were long before \rthis visible creation was the opinion of many ancient Fathers. To find \rout the truth of this prophecy, and what to determine thereon, he refers \rto a full council. What his associates thence attempt. L. l8 \r\r\r\rBOOK X. \r\r\r\r1 8 \r\r\r\rTHE ARGUMENT. \r\r\r\rMan\'s transgression known, the guardian Angels forsake Paradise, \rand return up to Heaven to approve their vigilance, and are approved ; \rGod declaring that the entrance of Satan could not be by them pre- \rvented. Sin and Death, sitting till then at the gates of Hell, by \rwondrous sympathy feeling the success of Satan in this new World, and \rthe sin by Man there committed, resolve to sit no longer confined in \rHell, but to follow Satan, their sire, up to the place of Man. According to the legend, Thammuz, son of \rCyneras, King of Byblus in Phoenicia, was slain by a boar in Lebanon ; \rbut every year his blood flowed afresh, and he came to life again there \rbeing annual festivals in his honour at Byblus and elsewhere, first to \rlament his death, then to celebrate his revival. Thammuz, \'sun of \rlife,\' is the Greek Adonis (the god of the solar year), and the story sym- \rbolises the alternation of summer and winter. The notion of his blood \rflowing again was due to the reddening of the waters of the river Adonis \r\r\r\rNOTES. 387 \r\rthrough the peculiar red mud brought down by spring torrents from the \rLebanon heights. M. alludes to the story in ix. 440, Mansus, n, and \rEikonoklastes, i (" let them who now mourn for him as for Thammuz, \rthem who howl in their pulpits" where "him" refers to Charles I.). \rThe story is given at some length in Sandys\' Relation, p. 209. \r\r450, 451. smooth, smooth-flowing. Spirits, we have seen (428), can contract themselves. \r\rA passage like this brings before us one of the great difficulties \rinherent in the design of Paradise Lost, namely the representation of \rthe angels, good and evil. Milton (says Johnson) "saw that immateriality \rsupplied no images, and that he could not show angels acting but by \rinstruments of action [i.e. bodies] ; he therefore invested them with \rform and matter" notably in his account (bk. vi.) of the battle in \rHeaven. Yet sometimes they are viewed as "incorporeal Spirits" \r(789), and it is seemingly as a spirit that Satan enters the form of \rthe toad (iv. 800), and of the Serpent (ix. 85, 86, 187 90). There \ris in fact some inconsistency: "his infernal and celestial powers are \rsometimes pure spirit, and sometimes animated body" (Johnson). The \rdifficulty is really insuperable, but Milton purposely modifies its effect, \r\r\r\rNOTES. 399 \r\rparticularly in the case of the evil angels, by several passages ; see the \rnotes on i. 42329, v. 478, vi. 327. As regards the good angels, \rI suppose he would have argued that divine beings had the power to \rassume corporeal forms and to resume their incorporeal being; whereas \rthe evil angels, through sin, gradually lost their immateriality and were \rforced "to incarnate and imbrute" (ix. 166). \r\r780, 781. L. \r\r27 \r\r\r\r41 8 PARADISE LOST. BOOK II. \r\rlimited to the only part of Africa south of the Red Sea which the \rancients knew, namely, its eastern coast. Gradually the use of the term \r"Ethiopia" expanded with the progress of Portuguese geographical \rdiscovery westward, until it applied to the vast region stretching from \rocean to ocean. The general idea of the "golden scales" of the Almighty \ris from Homer, Iliad vili. 69 72 : "then did the Father [i.e. Zeus] \rbalance his golden scales (xpv&eia raXavra) and put therein two fates of \rdeath. ..one for horse-taming Trojans, one for mail-clad Achaians; and \rhe took the scale-yard by the midst and lifted it, and the Achaians\' day \rof destiny sank down" (Leaf). The idea is repeated in //. xxn. 209 12, \rwith reference to the contest between Achilles and Hector, and imitated \rby Vergil, SEn. xil. 725 27, with reference to yEneas and Turaus. \r\rM. does not borrow without adding or varying, and we may note the \rfresh turns which he has given to Homer\'s notion: (i) he identifies the \rScales with the sign of the Zodiac called Libra\'\' the Balance\' a poetic \rfancy which gives at once a certain reality to the fiction of the Scales \rand a new association and interest to Libra itself; (2) he represents the \rScales as those with which the Almighty measured out the Universe \rand its elements and this, by adding to the importance of the Scales, \rheightens our sense of the greatness of Satan whose fate is weighed \rin them, and increases the grandeur of the whole scene. \r\rM. had referred to the Scales Fatorum lances in his Latin poem \rNaturam non Pati Senium, 34, 35. This is one of the passages in which the treatise on The \rChristian Doctrine is valuable as explaining Milton\'s philosophical and \rtheological views. Chapter 7 of the first book treats "Of the Creation," \rand he expounds at great length his conception of the "one first matter." \rHis views, as admirably summarised by Dr Masson, amount to this \r" that all created Being, whether called soul or body, consists of but \rone primordial matter, a direct efflux from the very substance of the \r\rEternal and Infinite Spirit that there are graduated varieties or \r\rsorts of this first material efflux from Deity, all radically one, but \rdifferentiated into an ascending series of forms, from the inorganic \ras the lowest, up to the vegetable, thence to the animal, thence to the \rhuman, and so to the angelic, or nearest in nature to the Divine \roriginal." This passage in fact gives us what Adam afterwards (509) \rcalls "the scale of Nature." \r\rThe long discourses and explanations which Milton puts in the \rmouth of Raphael seem to come much more naturally from him, an \rarchangel, than the discourses with which Beatrice enlightens Dante in \rthe Paradiso, e.g. on Free Will (v.), the Atonement (vn.), the motion \rof the heavenly bodies, such as the Primum Mobile (xxvn.), the \rCreation (xxix.). \r\r471. created all, i.e. all things created such (namely "good ") to a \rperfect degree, and all made of one first original matter. With this exordium compare I. I 26; III. I 55; IX. \ri 47. All four passages mark a significant stage in the development \rof the story, and in each passage the notion implied in "above the \rOlympian hill I soar" finds expression. The first serves as prelude to \rthe whole poem and indicates the subject ; the second transfers the \rscene of the action from Hell to Heaven, and later to the Earth ; \rthe third is a pause before the history of Creation is unfolded; and \rthe fourth prepares us for the Temptation and Fall of Man. Compare \rHomer\'s method of stopping to invoke the Muse afresh before some \rgreat event is narrated. Pope parodies this epic convention in the \rArgument and (very Miltonic) first lines of the fourth book of The \rDunciad. \r\rWe may note in these four passages the number of personal allu- \rsions, e.g. to Milton\'s consciousness of the greatness of his subject \r(i. 12 16, 2426, in. 54, 55, vn. 1215, ix. 1319, 4143); his \rblindness (in. 21 55, vn. 27); loneliness (vn. 28); and advanced \ryears (ix. 45). \r\ri . descend from Heaven ; cf. Horace\'s descende calo, . . Calliope Odes \rill. 4. i, 2. Here the invocation is specially appropriate as the scene \rof the action of the poem passes literally from Heaven to Earth (the \rCreation of which is about to be described). \r\r2 if rightly thou art called} an indication that he was conscious \rof using the name not in its usual classical sense. \r\r3. the Olympian hill\\ Mount Olympus (cf. Indeed, though he accepts the \rPtolemaic system throughout the poem, he makes Raphael refer to it \rand its later developments in not very complimentary terms (77 84) \rand seems to lean towards the Copernican theory. Grotius in his \rAdamus Exul, the tragedy on the Fall of Man with which M. is \rthought to have been acquainted, makes an angel explain to Adam the \rastronomical system and laws of the Universe. \r\rSome striking parallels to Milton\'s words are presented by the \rchapter in Burton\'s Anatomy of Melancholy entitled "a Digression of \rthe Ayre" (n. 2. in), which is a review of then current systems and \rtheories of astronomers. Astronomy (in which, as in so many other \rthings, he really belonged to a past generation) evidently had a great \rattraction for Milton : hence the references to Galileo, the only one of \rhis contemporaries alluded to \'in Paradise Lost. And how significant \rin itself is the famous reference in bk. I.! "\'The Tuscan artist\' \rthat is the name which Milton gives to Galileo, as if to indicate that \rscience and art are in inseparable conjunction, as they were in his own \rperson, and in his own poetry" (Mackail). But Dante had set the example. \r\r\r\rNOTES. 553 \r\r131 40. \'You must attribute the three motions just mentioned \reither to several spheres moving in opposite directions and crossing each \rother obliquely (the Ptolemaic view), or to the Earth (the Copernican \rview). If you attribute them to the Earth, then you save the Sun his \rlabour, i.e. of revolving round the Earth; and you also get rid of \r("save") that wheel or "rhomb" called the Primutn Mobile, the \rmotion of which is supposed to cause the revolution of the nine inner \rspheres round the Earth in twenty-four hours. It is only a theory that \rthis wheel or "rhomb" exists, because it is too far off to be visible; \rand you need not believe in the theory, if the Earth revolves on her \raxis from west to east every twenty-four hours, and thus illuminates \rwith the Sun\'s rays one-half of her globe while the other half, being \rturned away from ("averse") the Sun, is covered with darkness. BOOK IX. \r\r"Of the seven days during which Satan went round and round \rthe Earth, always keeping himself on its dark side, three were spent \rin moving from east to west on the equatorial line; four in moving \rround from pole to pole, [i.e.] from north to south and back, \rin which second way of moving he would traverse (or go along) the \rtwo colures, viz. two great circles, so named by astronomers, drawn \rfrom the poles. The reference is to the banyan-tree or Indian fig \r(Fiats religiosa or Indicd). Warton pointed out that M. has followed \rclosely cf. the numerous verbal similarities the account of this tree \rin Gerard\'s Herball, 1 597 (the standard Elizabethan work on botany), \rwhere it is called "the arched Indian Fig-tree." Gerard, who took \rhis information on the subject from Pliny, Natural History xn. 5, says : \r\r" The ends [of its branches] hang downe, and touch the ground, \rwhere they take roote and grow in such sort, that those twigs become \rgreat trees ; and these, being grown" up unto the like greatnesse, \rdo cast their branches or twiggy tendrels unto the earth, where they \rlikewise take hold and roote ; by meanes whereof it cometh to passe, \rthat of one tree is made a great wood or desart of trees, which \rthe Indians do use for couerture against the extreme heate of the \rsun. The winds are said to "roll the thunder" because they " roll " \rthe clouds which cause the thunder. \r\r668 78. Dr Masson explains : " It is poetically assumed here \rthat, before the Fall, the ecliptic or Sun\'s path was in the same plane as \rthe Earth\'s equator, and that the present obliquity of the two planes, or \rtheir intersection at an angle of 23^, was a modification of the physical \rUniverse for the worse, consequent upon the moral evil introduced by \rsin. But this physical alteration might be produced in either of two \r\r\r\rNOTES. 607 \r\rways : either by pushing askance the axis of the Earth the required \rdistance, leaving the Sun undisturbed ; or by leaving the Earth undis- \rturbed and compelling the Sun to deviate the required distance (\' like \rdistant breadth \') from his former equatorial or equinoctial path. To \rindicate what \' the like distant breadth\' would amount to, Milton follows \rthe Sun in imagination after his deviation from the equatorial line : \rtracing him, first, in his ascent north of the equator, through the constel- \rlations Taurus (in whose neck are the Pleiades, called the Seven \rAtlantic Sisters, as being mythologically the daughters of Atlas) and \rGemini (called \' the Spartan twins,\' as representing Castor and Pollux, \rthe twin-sons of Tyndarus, King of Sparta), up to his extreme distance \rfrom the equator at the Crab, in the Tropic of Cancer ; then returning \rwith him in his descending path by Leo and Virgo, till he again touches \rthe equator at Libra ; and, for the rest, simply suggesting his similar \rdeviation from the equator to the south by naming the Tropic of \rCapricorn as the farthest point reached on that side.... He [Milton] \rgives the larger space to the hypothesis of a change of the Sun\'s \rpath." \r\r671. the centric globe, the Earth, the centre of the Universe, \raccording to the Ptolemaic system. \r\r676. the Scales Libra (ill. 558). \r\r678, 679. In these lines M. first traces the journey of Abraham to \rthe Promised Land (cf. The four boundaries are : (i) the town (or district) of \rHamath, in Upper Syria, lying in the valley of the Orontes ; afterwards \rcalled Epiphaneia by Antiochus Epiphanes, and now again known as \rHamah ; expressly mentioned as the northern limit of Canaan in Numb. \rxxxiv. 7, 8. (2) The Desert of Zin, forming part of the southern frontier \rof the Holy Land (Numb, xxxiv. 3). (3) Mt Hermon, \' the lofty peak \' ; \rthe most conspicuous mountain in Palestine, and the great landmark \rof the Israelites. In Scripture Hermon is associated with, not the \reastern but, the northern boundary; cf. Ps. Ixxxix. 12, "The north \rand the south thou hast created them : Tabor and Hermon shall rejoice \rin thy name." Perhaps this was why M. afterwards added that the \rJordan was the "true limit eastward." (4) The "western sea," i.e. \rthe Mediterranean ; cf. BOOK XII. \r\rdouble-founted\\ probably an allusion to the old belief that the \rJordan, in its upper course, was formed by the union of two streams \rthought to give the river its name; these were the Dan and i\\\\z Jor, \rand their supposed place of confluence lay near Caesarea Philippi. Shakespearian tragedy usually ends on a \rquiet note. \r\r\r\rAPPENDIX. \r\r\r\rTHE COSMOLOGY OF PARADISE LOST. \r\rPARTS of Paradise Lost are not easily understood without some \rknowledge of Milton\'s conception of the Universe. I shall attempt \rtherefore to set forth some of the main aspects of his cosmology : to \rexplain, in fact, what he means by constantly recurrent terms such as \r\' Empyrean,\' Chaos,\' * Spheres,\' and the like. \r\rIt is in book v. that he carries us back farthest in respect of time. \rThe events described by Raphael (from line 563, onwards) precede not \ronly the Creation of the World, but also the expulsion of the rebels \rfrom Heaven. And at this era, when the seeds of discord are being \rsown, we hear of two divisions of Space Heaven and Chaos : Heaven \rlying above Chaos. \r\rIn book vi. the contest foreshadowed in book V. has begun. Now \ra third region is mentioned Hell (vi. 53 55) : a gloomy region carved \rout of the nethermost depths of Chaos. Its remoteness from Heaven \rmay be inferred from I. 73, 74. Milton\'s working hypothesis, then \rhis general conception of space and its partitionment prior to the \rCreation may be expressed roughly thus: above 1 , Heaven; beneath, \rHell ; between, a great gulf, Chaos. \r\rLet us see what he has to say concerning each. \r\rHeaven, or the Empyrean 2 , is the abode of the Deity and His \rangelic subjects. It is a vast region, but not infinite. In x. 380 \rMilton speaks of its "empyreal bounds"; in n. 1049 of its "battle- \rments 3 "; in vi. 860 of its "crystal wall." These fence Heaven in \r\r1 i.e. from the point of view of this World, the position of which we shall see. \r\r2 The terms are synonymous. What is this globe as Milton, following the \rastronomy of his 2 time, has described it? \r\rThe globe as then conceived may best be likened (in Plato\'s \rcomparison 3 ) to one of those puzzles or boxes in which are contained \ra number of boxes of gradually lessening size : remove the first, and \ryou shall find another inside, rather smaller: remove the second, and \ryou shall come on a third, still smaller: and so on, till you reach \rthe centre the kernel, as it were, round which the different boxes \rwere but successive shells. Now, of the globe of the World the \rEarth (they said) is the kernel (is it not often called \'the centre 4 \'?); \rand a stationary body itself it is encased by numerous shells or \rSpheres : the number of the Spheres being a subject of dispute and \rvarying in the different astronomical systems. Milton, accepting 5 for \rthe purposes of his epic the Ptolemaic system as expanded by the \rastronomer Alphonsus X. of Castille, recognises ten Spheres. A \rSphere, it should be noted, is merely a circular region of space \rnot necessarily of solid matter. Indeed, of the ten Spheres only one, \rthe Primum Mobile, appears in Milton\'s description to consist of some \rmaterial substance. Seven of them are the Spheres of the planets, \ri.e. the orbits in which the planets severally move. \r\r\r\r1 x. 320 24. \r\r8 I do not mean to imply that the Ptolemaic system was still generally believed in \rat the time when /\'. L. was published, but that it satisfied Elizabethan writers, of \rwhom Milton was the last. \r\r" On the slowness with which the Coperaican theory was diffused, and especially \rBacon\'s opposition to it, see Whewell\'s History of the Inductive Sciences, i. 404 \r12, ed. 1847. Copernicus died in 1543, and his opinions were introduced into \rEngland mainly through Giordano Bruno, who came over about 1583" (note in \rClarendon Press ed. of The Advancement of Learning, p. 294). \r\rs See the Myth of Er in the Republic 617, 618; and the note on Arcades, 64, where \rthe passage is translated. \r\r* Cf. perhaps i. 686; and certainly The Winter\'s Tale, n. i. 102, Troilns \rand Cressida, i. 3. 85. \r\r6 He was evidently familiar with the Copernican system (cf. iv. 592 97, vni. 130 \r40, notes); and the question has been asked why he did not follow it in the poem. \rThe Copernican theory was new, without a scrap of literary association and with no \rpoetic terminology: whereas the Ptolemaic view and its delightful fictions as to the \rSpheres, their harmonies, and the like, had become a tradition of literature, expressed \rin terms that recalled Marlowe and Shakespeare and Jonson and the sacri vates of \rEnglish verse. To surrender this poetic heritage merely out of deference to science \rhad been impossible pedantry a perverse concession to the cold philosophy that \r" empties the haunted air and unweaves the rainbow " (Lamia). \r\r\r\rAPPENDIX. 665 \r\rThe order of the Spheres, which fit one within the other 1 , is, if we \rstart from the Earth as the stationary centre 2 of the Universe, as \rfollows: first, the Spheres of the planets successively the Moon, \rMercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn ; then, outside the \rlast of these (i.e. Saturn), the Firmament or Cselum Stellatum, in which \rare set the \' fixed stars \' ; then, outside the Firmament, the Crystalline \rSphere ; and last, the Primum Mobile enclosing all the others. Com- \rpare the famous lines (481 83) in book ill. describing the passage \rof the souls of the departed from Earth to Heaven : \r\r"They pass the planets seven, and pass the fixed, \rAnd that crystalline sphere whose balance weighs \rThe trepidation talked, and that first moved." \r\rIt remains to note three or four points in these lines. Milton treats \rthe Sun and Moon as planets (v. 17177, x. 651 58). Compare \rTroilus and Cressida, I. 3. 89, "the glorious planet Sol," and Antony \rand Cleopatra, v. 2. 240, 241 : \r\r"now the fleeting moon \rNo planet is of mine." \r\rThe \'fixed stars\' are referred to four times in the poem but only once \r(v. 176) with the word \'star\' added: in the other places (111.481, x. \r661) they are called simply "the fixed " or " fixed " (v. 621). Though \rthey are unmoved their Sphere revolves round the Earth, moving from \rEast to W r est, completing a revolution in twenty-four hours, and carrying \rwith it the seven inner Spheres 3 . The rapid motion of this Sphere is \rglanced at in V. 176 ("their orb 4 that flies"). The Crystalline Sphere \rand the Primum Mobile were not included in the original Ptolemaic \rsystem. They were added later, to explain certain phenomena which \rthe earlier astronomers had not observed, and for which their theories \roffered no explanation. Thus the supposed swaying or "trepidation" \rof the Crystalline Sphere was held to be the cause of the precession of \rthe equinoxes. This Sphere is described as a vast expanse of waters \r(see the note on VII. 261 74).
