First, as to the rank which \rMilton assigns to him before his revolt, and the cause of that revolt. \rMilton speaks of Satan as an archangel 1 "if not the first Archangel" \r(v. 660) : that is, he is inclined to give Satan pre-eminence over all \rangelic beings. But this pre-eminence is not emphasised so much as we \rmight have expected. \r\rThe immediate cause of the rebellion in Heaven is the proclamation \rthat all should worship the Messiah as their Head (v. 600 15). Satan \rresents the command, conceiving himself " impaired" (v. 665) thereby; \rand he makes its pretended injustice a means of drawing away a \rthird part of the angels from their allegiance. They are equal, he \rsays, to the Messiah : self-begotten, not created : not liable to pay \rworship; and so, playing on their pride, he wins them (v. 772 \r802, 853 69). Meantime, in his own heart an even stronger motive \ris at work ; to wit, jimbition to be himself equal to the Deity \rnay, superior. He not only disclaims submission to the Son : he \rstrives "against the throne and monarchy" (i. 42) of the Almighty \rHimself; and it is as the foe rather of the Father than of the Son that \rthe great archangel is set before us in Paradise Lost. \r\rTouching both matters there was much tradition, whereof it may be \rinteresting to cite two or three illustrations from popular works 2 with \rwhich Milton is likely to have been familiar. Tradition, literary no less than theological, prescribed \rthe dominant idea in that nature : enough if Milton developed the idea \rin harmony with the design of his poem. This he did. He depicts \rSatan as an embodiment of the spirit of pride and ambition 2 : not the \rambition which is an honourable desire of praise that last infirmity of \rnoble minds but the fevered lust for power which springs from over- \rmastering self-esteem. In Satan this spirit of egotism is the poison \rthat permeates his whole being, vanquishing and vitiating all that \ris good in him. \r\rFor at the outset of the action of Paradise Lost Satan has much that \ris noble and attractive in his nature. To have made him wholly evil \rhad repelled, and lessened the interest of the poem, which turns, in no \rslight degree, on the struggle between the good and evil elements in \rhim. Indeed, this very pride is not without its good aspect. Herein \rlies the motive power that nerves him at every crisis to face insuperable \rdifficulties ; to cherish immortal hope though hope of revenge ; and \rto adventure "high attempts." \r\rOn the other hand, it is this same spirit that drives him onward to \rhis final fall. To \rsue for grace were to humble himself in the eyes of his followers and \rin his own : which must not be (iv. 79 86). \r\rSteadily does Milton keep this idea before us. There is no possi- \rbility of missing or mistaking his intention. A bird flying \rfrom the Himalayas to the sources of the Ganges would not pass over \r\r\r\r684 PARADISE LOST. \r\rany part of \' Sericana,\' by which, probably, the north-west angle of the \rChinese Empire was signified. But I think that Milton does mean us to regard Imaus \ras the starting-point of the bird\'s flight. \r\r" Imaus," however, need not mean the Himalayas in this passage. \rTrue, the earlier classical geographers applied "Imaus" to the \rHimalayas (the names being cognate) ; but in Ptolemy and later writers \rthe name is transferred to the great chain of mountains, the Bolor \rrange, which runs through Central Asia from North to South, dividing \rthe Chinese Empire from Turkestan. And this later use 1 of " Imaus" \rappears to have been that recognised by geographers of the iyth \rcentury. Perhaps the best known collection of maps issued in England \rbetween 1600 and 1650 was the English edition 2 of Mercator\'s Atlas ^ \rdoubtless known to Milton. \r\rNow, in Mercator\'s map of Tartaria there is marked a chain of \rmountains called Imaus Mons. It extends, roughly speaking, from \rthe north-eastern corner of the modern Afghanistan to the "Frozen \rOcean," i.e. Arctic Ocean. Its course is due North and South. When \rMilton speaks of "Imaus" which bounds the "roving Tartars" he \rmeans, I doubt not, this Imaus Mons which is so conspicuous \rin Mercator\'s Tartaria. And any one who could consult this rare \rAtlas would perceive at once the accuracy of Milton\'s description. For \rthe northern part of Imaus Mons does " bound " the Tartar, sepa- \rrating his country from Russia; and a vulture starting from this \rnorthern part and flying southward to the Ganges would pass over the \rnorth-west plains of the Chinese Empire. Judged therefore from the \r1 7th century standpoint the geography of the passage is quite correct. \rOf course, very little was known then about Central Asia. See also Comus, 517. \r\r\r\rJ- \r\rPARADISE LOST, VH. 112. \r\rMilton\'s invocation is addressed to the Muse of sacred song and \rinspiration the Heavenly power which "taught" Moses on Sinai \r(i. 6 10), and inspired David on Sion (HI. 29 32) and the other \rprophets and singers of Israel. It is to her that he appeals at the \rbeginning of the poem " Sing, Heavenly Muse," and there is a special \rappropriateness in lines 6 10. Cf. Addison\'s remark: "His invo- \rcation to a work which turns in a great measure upon the creation of \rthe World, is very properly made to the muse who inspired Moses in \rthose books from whence our author drew his subject, and to the Holy \rSpirit who is therein represented as operating after a particular manner \rin the first production of nature." \r\rAs to the character of this divine power whose existence he postu- \rlates, he does not, naturally, speak with definiteness: in I. 17 26 he \rexpressly distinguishes her from the Holy Spirit; in P. R. i. 8 17 he \rseems to identify them. \r\rThe important point is that for Milton this " Heavenly Muse " is a \rtruly divine power, in whom he believes with a conviction which gives \rintense reality to his invocations. \r\rWith the classical poets (Homer perhaps excepted) the invocation of \rthe Muse was, I suppose, merely a literary convention a piece of the \rtraditional * machinery \' of poetry : one does not credit Horace with \rmuch faith in the Calliope whom he begged to "descend from Heaven." \r\r\r\rAPPENDIX. 687 \r\rMilton has faith, and when he asks Urania to aid him he means every \rword of his petition. \r\rIt is in virtue too of his assistance by this higher and holier power \rthan the classical poets knew of that he speaks of his poetry as soaring \r"above" theirs. Compare vn. 3, 4 and I. 12 15, where, addressing \rthe " Heavenly Muse," he says : \r\r"I \r\rInvoke thy aid to my adventurous song, \rThat with no middle flight intends to soar \rAbove the Aonian mount" (i.e. Mt Helicon). \r\rHe does not, I think, intend to suggest that he will surpass, say, \rVergil as an artist as a master of style and imagery and other qualities \rwhich constitute the art of poetry; but only that he is filled with a \rhigher inspiration to treat of higher things. In fact, his claim is to \rmoral, not artistic, superiority ; it resolves itself almost into the differ- \rence between Christianity and Paganism. We should remember that \rin Milton\'s eyes the poet is a teacher in the first place, a singer in the \rsecond : he must write " to God\'s glory, by the honour and instruction \rof his country," and be "an interpreter and relater of the best andsagest \rthings among his own citizens." See the preface to book u. of The \rReason of Church Government, and cf. the Introduction to this volume. \rThe name " Urania" which he assigns to his Muse means, of course, \r1 the Heavenly One,\' Gk. otpavla 1 . In classical mythology Urania was \rcommonly regarded as the Muse of astronomy; compare a poem on \r" The Muses" by Nicholas Grimald: \r\r" Uranie, her globes to view all bent, \r\rThe ninefolde heauen observes with fixed face 8 ." \rIn these lines Urania evidently typifies astronomy according to the \rordinary classical conception of her attributes ; and a similar illustra- \rtion might be cited from Sylvester\'s Du Bartas (Grosart\'s ed., n. 3). \rIn treating Urania otherwise than as the Muse of astronomy Milton had \rbeen anticipated by other poets. Perhaps the earliest was Dante ; cf. \rthe Purgatorio, xxix. 4042 : " Now \'tis meet that Helicon for me \rstream forth and Urania aid me with her choir to set in verse things 3 \rhard to conceive." Dante had been followed by English poets. Spenser, \rfor example, in The Ttares of the Muses makes her represent the highest \rknowledge "the heavenlie light of knowledge "; while for Drummond \rof Hawthornden she meant, it would seem, the power of spiritual wisdom, \rone section of his poems being entitled " Urania, or Spiritual Poems." \r\r1 See Hesiod, Theogony 78. \r\r* Tottel\'s Miscellany. 1557, e d. From very remote antiquity, however, it had \rbeen perceived that the simple circular motions of eight or even ten \rspheres round the Earth, with whatever variety of rates and times among \rthemselves, would not account for all the observed phenomena of the \rheavens, would not account, for example, for the fact that the motion \rof the Sun is faster or slower according to the season (acceleration and \rretardation), or for the fact that the motions of the planets are sometimes \rdirect, or in the order of the signs of the Zodiac, and sometimes \rretrograde (progression and regression). To remedy this defect, \' to \rsave these appearances,\' two devices had been introduced, that of the \rEccentric and that of the Epicycle. \r\r4 \'Let it be supposed that, while the Earth is the centre of the Primum \rMobile [i.e. the outermost of the spheres] and consequently of the \rwhole mundane system, the inclosed planetary spheres, or at all events \rthat of the Sun, need not be strictly concentric, i.e. need not strictly \rhave this centre, but may be eccentric, i.e. may revolve round a point \rsomewhat to the side of the Earth ; then, as the Earth would sometimes \rbe nearer to the moving body, and sometimes farther off, the accelera- \rtion or retardation of the motion would be sufficiently accounted for. \r\r\r\rAPPENDIX. 689 \r\r" Again, let it be supposed that the body of a planet is not fixed strictly \rin its cycle, or the circumference of its wheeling sphere, but moves \rflylike in an epicycle, or small circle revolving round a fixed point in \rthat wheeling circumference ; then, according as the planet was in that \rpart of its epicycle which is beyond, or in that part which is within, its \rcycle, its motion would for the time be progressive, i.e. with its cycle, \ror retrograde, i.e. against its cycle. Actually, by a complicated use of \rthese two devices,... the Ptolemaic astronomers had contrived, with a \rtolerable approach to completeness, to account for all the phenomena of \rthe solar and planetary motions, but only by such a dizzying intricacy \rof conceived wheels within wheels (\'centric and eccentric" 1 ) and wheels \rupon wheels (\' cycle and epicycle" 1 } as Milton describes." \r\rThere is a great deal about these theories of the Eccentric and \rEpicycle in Burton\'s Anatomy of Melancholy, ir. i. in, the chapter \rentitled "a Digression of the Ayre"; see especially pp. 381, 382, 384 \rin the ninth edition (1800). Like Milton, he ridicules the too-ingenious \rspeculations of astronomers, who, " to solve all appearances and \robjections, have invented new hypotheses, and fabricated new systems \rof the World... The World is tossed in a blanket amongst them, they \rhoyse the Earth up and down like a ball, make it stand and go at their \rpleasures " (pp. 388, 389). \r\rCompare also Bacon\'s Essay Of Superstition : \r\r"It was gravely said of the prelates in the Council of Trent, where \rthe doctrine of the Schoolmen bare great sway, that the Schoolmen \rwere like astronomers, which did feign eccentrics and epicycles, and \rsuch engines of orbs, to save tht phenomena 1 , though they knew there \rwere no such things ; and, in like manner, that the Schoolmen had \rframed a number of subtle and intricate axioms and theorems to save the \rpractice of the Church." See also his Essay Of Wisdom for a Man\'s \rSelf. \r\rSo in The Advancement of Learning, n. 8. 5 : \r\r"As the same phenomena in astronomy are satisfied by the received \rastronomy of the diurnal motion, and the proper motions of the planets, \rwith their eccentrics and epicycles, and likewise by the theory of \rCopernicus, who supposed the earth to move, and the calculations are \rindifferently agreeable to both, so the ordinary face and view of \rexperience is many times satisfied by several theories and philosophies ; \rwhereas to find the real truth requireth another manner of severity and \rattention" (Clarendon ed., p. 127). \r\rSir Thomas Browne uses this astronomical metaphor in charac- \rteristic fashion: \r\r1 Echoed, perhaps, in Milton\'s phrase (vm. 82). \rP. L. 44 \r\r\r\r690 PARADISE LOST. \r\r"In philosophy, where truth seems double-faced, there is no man \rmore paradoxical than myself: but in divinity I love to keep the road ; \rand, though not in an implicit, yet an humble faith, follow the great \rwheel of the Church, by which I move ; not reserving any proper \rpoles, or motion from the epicycle of my own brain" (Religio Medici, \rI. vi.). \r\rCompare too his Christian Morals, I. xix.: " Hang early plummets \rupon the heels of pride, and let ambition have but an epicycle and \rnarrow circuit in thee." \r\rFor eccentric, see the note on v. 623, and compare one of Milton\'s \rfavourite astronomical metaphors in The Reason of Church Government, \rI. i : \r\r"Yet is it to be conceived that.. .our happiness ["of the blessed in \rparadise "] may orb itself into a thousand vagancies of glory and delight, \rand with a kind of eccentrical equation be, as it were, an invariable \rplanet of joy and felicity" (P. The question was first raised \rby Dryden in the Discourse on Satire (1693) prefixed to his translation \rof Juvenal, thus : \r\r"As for Mr Milton, whom we all admire with so much justice, his \rsubject is not that of an heroic poem, properly so called. His design \ris the losing of our happiness ; his event [i.e. end, termination] is not \rprosperous, like that of all other epic works ; his heavenly machines are \rmany, and his human persons are but two." And, " besides questioning \rwhether * Paradise Lost \' was an heroic poem, Dryden had argued [in the \rpreface to Vergil\\ that the devil was the hero and not Adam 1 ." \r\rAddison said : " I shall waive the discussion of that point, which was \rstarted some years since, whether Milton\'s \' Paradise Lost \' may be \rcalled an heroic poem. Those who will not give it that title may call it \r(if they please) a divine poem." Addison held that an heroic poem \rshould not end unhappily and that therefore Paradise Lost, to this \rextent, forfeits the title " heroic " ; but he argued that the defect was \rinherent in the subject, and that Milton showed exquisite judgment and \rinvention in remedying it (see the note on XI. 35658). \r\r1 C. H. Firth, Johnson\'s Lift of Milton, p. 135. Several of the passages in this \rsection are taken from his full note. \r\r\r\rAPPENDIX. 691 \r\rJohnson dealt with the objection more summarily : \r"The questions, whether the action of the poem be strictly one, \rwhether the poem can be properly termed heroic, and who is the hero, \rare raised by such readers as draw their principles of judgment rather \rfrom books than from reason. Five Conjunction, \rSextile, Square, Trine, and Diametral or Opposition. What is the \rfirst? When two \rplanets or stars are distant from each other a sixth part of the Zodiac, \rviz. two signs or 60. When the \rdistance of the stars measures a third of the circle, that is 120 or four \rsigns. What is the Diametral aspect ? Paradise \rLost, therefore, though published in 1667, is best illustrated from the \rworks of the generation contemporary with Shakespeare. Hence many \rof the illustrations in the Glossary and Notes are taken from the writers \rwho may collectively and conveniently be described as Elizabethan. \r\rA marked feature of Milton\'s diction, as of his style, is his classical \rbias. He employs many words in their classical sense, just as he \remploys many classical idioms and figures of speech. This classicism \rof diction is still more conspicuous in his prose, in which he introduces \rnumbers of long, sonorous words derived from the Latin. Sometimes \rhe invents such words. Paradise Lost contains innumerable examples \rof his classical diction. \r\rAnother interesting feature is his partiality for Italianised forms. \rThis is more conspicuous in his verse, perhaps because he felt so \rstrongly, and wished his readers to be reminded of, the spell and \rfascination of the great Italian epics. By his own statement, he had \rstudied Italian much before he went to Italy. His letters and prose- \rworks reveal his love of it (I do not remember any interesting reference \rin his works to French literature) ; and several short poems testify to \rhis very considerable mastery of the language. Lat. triumphus G\\a. dplapfios, \ra hymn to Bacchus. \r\rtroll, xi. 620, \'to roll\'; still used in its literal sense in many counties, \re.g. to troll a ball or hoop or wheel. In Yorkshire *7V0//-egg-day\' was \ran old name for Easter-Monday and Shrove-Tuesday, because on those \rdays children played with hard-boiled, dyed eggs, rolling them on the \rgrass. \r\runcouth, ii. 407, 827; A.S. uncuft, \'unknown\' from un, \'not\' \r+ cttf$, the p.p. of cunnan, \'to know.\' In M. it means \'strange, un- \r\rP. L. 46 \r\r\r\r722 PARADISE LOST. \r\rfamiliar,\' perhaps with the implied notion \' unpleasant\'; cf. V. 98, VI. \r362. So in Titus Andronicns, n. 3. 211, "I am surprised with an \runcouth fear," and As You Like //, n. 6. 6. \r\runenvled, II. 23. Elizabethan writers constantly treat the termi- \rnation -ed, which belongs to the passive participle, as equal to the \radjectival ending -able; especially with words which have the negative \rprefix -, and the sense \'that may not be.\' Cf. II. 337, 903. So \r" unvalued " = \' invaluable,\' " unavoided " = \' inevitable,\' Richard III. \rI. 4. 27, IV. 4. 217. The use of the participial and adjectival endings \rwas less regular then than now. \r\runweeting, x. 335, 916. M. always uses this form, never unwitting; \rthe ee represents the sound of the long / in A.S. wttan, \' to know,\' \rwhich comes from the same root as Gk. olda and ISelv and Lat. videre. \r\rutter, i. 72, ill. 16, V. 614; the comparative of A.S. #/, \'out,\' \rand an older form of outer. Lawyers still speak of " the utter bar" in \rcontrast with "the inner bar." Cf. Blount\'s Glossographia (1656): \r"The outward or Utter Barristers... these always plead without [i.e. \routside] the Bar." In Ezekiel x. 5 the Bible used to read "utter \rcourt." \r\rvans, n. 927, \'wings\'; Ital. vanni, from Lat. vannus, \'a winnowing- \rfan." 1 Cf. P. R. iv. 583, "plumy vans" (said of angels\' wings), and \rTennyson\'s Love and Death, "Love wept and spread his sheeny vans \rfor flight." For van=fan cf. vat = fat as in \' wine^/a/.\' The Manipuhis \rVocabulorum (1570) gives an old verb "to vanne, vannarc? i.e. \'to \rwinnow.\' \r\rvirtue; often (vn. 236, vin. 95, ix. no, 145, 616, 649) used by M. \rin the sense \'efficacy, might\' ; cf. Luke viii. 46, "virtue is gone out of \rme": hence virtuous= \'full of efficacy\' (ix. 795, 1033). Also = \' courage \' \r(i. 320, X. 372), i.e. what a man (vir) should specially be, viz. \'brave\'; \rLat. virtus, \'worth, manly excellence, valour\' (Lat. vir, \' man \'). This \retymological use is well illustrated in the Life of Coriolanus in North\'s \rPlutarch : "Now in those days valiantness was honoured in Rome above \rall other virtues: which they call virtus, by the name of virtue itself, \ras including in that general name all other special virtues besides. So \rthat virtus in the Latin was as much as valiantness. " \r\rvouchsafe, n. 332, vii. 80, vin. 8. Spelt voutsafe in the original \reditions, and perhaps we ought to keep the form, as some editors do. \rM. may have wished to avoid the awkward sound ch before s, just as \rin proper names he avoids sh. \r\rwaft, ii. 1042 ; often used (as here) by Elizabethan writers with the \rsense \' to journey, or carry, over water.\' Cf. 2 Henry VI. iv. r. 114, \r" I charge thee waft me safely cross the Channel "; and P. R. i. 104. \r\r\r\rGLOSSARY. 723 \r\rwanton. The word means literally \'unrestrained \' ; hence \'luxuriant,\' \ras used of growth, IX. 211. Cf. A Midsummer- Night\'s Dream, n. i. \r99, 100: \r\r"And the quaint mazes in the wanton green \r\rFor lack of tread are undistinguishable." \r\rOf motion it implies \' tossing about,\' e.g. like the \' undulating \' coils \rof a serpent (ix. 517). \r\rwarp, I. 341 ; a nautical term (Scandinavian) = " to move into some \rdesired place or position by hauling on a rope or warp which has been \rfastened to something fixed, as a buoy, anchor, or other ship at or near \rthat place or position : as, to warp a ship into harbor or to her berth " \r(Century Diet.}. M. uses it to describe \'undulatory forward motion,\' \rand Thomson imitates him ; cf. Spring : \r\r"Myriads on myriads, insect armies warp \r\rKeen in the poisoned breeze." \rIn either case comparison with a sailing ship is implied. \r\rweed, \'a garment\'; A.S. weed, \'a garment, dress.\' Quite a Miltonic \rword; cf. L? Allegro, 119, 120: \r\r"Where throngs of knights and barons bold, \r\rIn weeds of peace, high triumphs hold " ; \r\rwhich is an echo of Troilus and Cressida, in. 3. 239, "To see great \rHector in his weeds of peace." So in Coimts, 16, 84, and 390 (" For \rwho would rob a hermit of his weeds? "). The singular is rare, but cf. \rA Midsummcr-Nighfs Dream, 11. i. 255, 256: \r\r"And there the snake throws her enamell\'d skin, \r\rWeed wide enough to wrap a fairy in." \r\rNow a poetical or dialect (e.g. Scottish) usage, apart from the phrase \r"widow\'s weeds"; cf. Tennyson, In Mcmoriam, v. : \r\r"In words like weeds, I\'ll wrap me o\'er." \r\rwelkin, \'sky\'; properly a plural word =\' clouds \'; cf. Germ, wolke, \r\'a cloud.\' The termination -in (for -en] is the plural ending which \rwe get in brethren, children, oxen. M. uses welkin only twice (n. 538, \rComus, 1015), and it was perhaps an affected word (Twelfth Night, \rin. i. 65). \r\rwignt, ii. 613, \' person, being\' ; A.S. iviht, \'a creature.\' It was \rrather an old-fashioned word of ballad-poetry; Shakespeare seems to \rridicule it, putting it in the mouth of the bombastic Pistol; cf. The \rMerry Wives of Windsor, I. 3. 23, Henry V. II. i. 64. \r\rwon, vn. 457, \'dwell\'; cf. The Faerie Queene, n. 7. 49, "The \rfairest wight that wonneth under skie." From A.S. wiinian, which \rmeant (i) \'to dwell,\' (2) \'to be accustomed\'; now obsolete except in \rthe second sense and in the past participle wont or wonted. Similarly \r\r46 2 \r\r\r\r724 PARADISE LOST. \r\rthe cognate Germ. wohnen-=(i] \'to dwell,\' (2) \'to be wont.\' M. uses \rwont, in the second sense \'to be accustomed,\' as a present tense and a \rpreterite; though I. 764 and the Nativity Ode, 10, seem the only un- \rdoubted cases of the latter. \r\rwreak, iv. u, \'to avenge.\' This was the original sense of wreak \r(cognate with Germ, rdcken, \'to avenge\').
